citations.narrative:
The dogs are not receiving the required physical exam by the attending veterinarian every 12 months. Documentation
showed that some of the dogs had received physical exams from the veterinarian in June 2021. The licensee stated that
the next physical exam by the veterinarian occurred in October 2022 and only some of the dogs received a physcial exam
while others were just observed by the attending veterinarian. Failure to have each dog physically examined by the
veterinarian every 12 months may allow medical conditions to go unnoticed which could have a negative impact on the
health and well-being of the dogs.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that includes a complete physical examination from
head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months. The licensee must ensure that
each dog is physically examined by the attending veterinarian at least once every 12 months in order to support their
health and well-being.
To be corrected by: From this day forward the licensee must ensure each dog receives the physical examination once
every 12 months.

The licensee has acquired a new Attending Veterinarian and a new Program of Veterinary Care. The Program of
Veterinary Care is incomplete and the written schedule for treating intestinal parasites in adult dogs could not be located.
The licensee stated that the adult dogs are dewormed twice a year. Failure to document the deworming schedule may
interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the dogs are receiving adequate veterinary care.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is documented in writing and addresses
the requirements for adequate veterinary care and includes the sampling and treatment plan for parasites. The licensee
must add the deworming schedule for adult dogs to the Program of Veterinary Care to ensure the animals are receiving
adequate veterinary care.
To be corrected by: 02-March-2023

The licensee is using invoices from the attending veterinarian as medical records to document treatments and procedures
the dogs have undergone. Many of these invoices do not contain the identification of the dog that received the treatment
including an invoice that lists a dog which received a dental cleaning and extraction and a puppy which received a hernia
repair. Official identification documented on medical records is necessary for APHIS officials to determine which dog the
record belongs to and if the animal has received adequate veterinary care.
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that include the identity of the animal including identifying marks,
tattoos, or tags and the animal's breed, sex and age. The licensee must ensure that all medical records contain the
identification of the animal as well as all other required information.
To be corrected by: From this day forward

The licensee had some of the dogs physically examined by the attending veterinarian in October 2022. No medical
record could be provided documenting which dogs were examined and the results of the exams. Failure to document
examinations and the results may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving
adequate veterinary care.
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that include the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or
other required or recommended tests or examinations. The licensee must document on a medical record each time a dog
is physically examined and the results of those exams. The licensee must ensure that all medical records are complete
and contain all required information.
To be corrected by: From this day forward
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The dogs are not receiving the required physical exam by the attending veterinarian every 12 months.  Documentation 
showed that some of the dogs had received physical exams from the veterinarian in June 2021.  The licensee stated that 
the next physical exam by the veterinarian occurred in October 2022 and only some of the dogs received a physcial exam 
while others were just observed by the attending veterinarian.  Failure to have each dog physically examined by the 
veterinarian every 12 months may allow medical conditions to go unnoticed which could have a negative impact on the 
health and well-being of the dogs. 
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that includes a complete physical examination from 
head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months.  The licensee must ensure that 
each dog is physically examined by the attending veterinarian at least once every 12 months in order to support their 
health and well-being. 
 
To be corrected by:  From this day forward the licensee must ensure each dog receives the physical examination once 
every 12 months. 
3.13(a)(3)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee has acquired a new Attending Veterinarian and a new Program of Veterinary Care.  The Program of 
Veterinary Care is incomplete and the written schedule for treating intestinal parasites in adult dogs could not be located.  
The licensee stated that the adult dogs are dewormed twice a year.  Failure to document the deworming schedule may 
interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the dogs are receiving adequate veterinary care.   
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is documented in writing and addresses 
the requirements for adequate veterinary care and includes the sampling and treatment plan for parasites.  The licensee 
must add the deworming schedule for adult dogs to the Program of Veterinary Care to ensure the animals are receiving 
adequate veterinary care.   
 
To be corrected by:  02-March-2023 
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is using invoices from the attending veterinarian as medical records to document treatments and procedures 
the dogs have undergone.  Many of these invoices do not contain the identification of the dog that received the treatment 
including an invoice that lists a dog which received a dental cleaning and extraction and a puppy which received a hernia 
repair.  Official identification documented on medical records is necessary for APHIS officials to determine which dog the 
record belongs to and if the animal has received adequate veterinary care. 
 
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that include the identity of the animal including identifying marks, 
tattoos, or tags and the animal's breed, sex and age.  The licensee must ensure that all medical records contain the

identification of the animal as well as all other required information. 
 
To be corrected by:  From this day forward 
3.13(b)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee had some of the dogs physically examined by the attending veterinarian in October 2022.  No medical 
record could be provided documenting which dogs were examined and the results of the exams.  Failure to document 
examinations and the results may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving 
adequate veterinary care.   
 
Each dealer shall keep copies of medical records that include the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or 
other required or recommended tests or examinations.  The licensee must document on a medical record each time a dog 
is physically examined and the results of those exams.  The licensee must ensure that all medical records are complete 
and contain all required information.   
 
To be corrected by:  From this day forward 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
